section.title: Secondary Sources
section.content: Lawyering I 2010 Secondary Sources
Learn primary vs. secondary authority Identify legal secondary sources Understand when to use which source Examine finding aids within each source Secondary Sources

section.title: Planning Your Research
section.content: Planning Your Research Analyze your facts (Things, Relief, causes of Action and defenses, People, Places) Secondary Sources Common Law or Statutory Law? Common Law Read cases referenced in Secondary Sources Use Digests to find cases Statutory Use Annotated Code Update code with pocket part and Legislative Service Shepardize or Keycite cases Read cases Shepardize code section Read cases cited in code section

section.content: Secondary Source Research

section.title: Legal Dictionaries
section.content: Legal Dictionaries Get definitions of words Provide synonyms Subject specific Dictionaries (i.e., tax, accounting, employment) Words and Phrases -- judicially interpreted

section.title: Encyclopedias
section.content: Encyclopedias Use for background Not deeply analytical Limited Citation to primary sources

section.content: Encyclopedias

section.title: How to Locate and Use an Encyclopedia in Lexis
section.content: How to Locate and Use an Encyclopedia in Lexis 1 Under Legal Tab, Click on Secondary Legal (you will need to Scroll down) Find and click on link for the encyclopedia 2 Or click on the link for Jurisprudences & Encyclopedias

section.title: Quiz Instructions - Quiz
section.content: Quiz Instructions - Quiz Wake up! Time to review some of what you’ve learned so far. Please answer the following questions. Click Play or Next button on Playbar to start the quiz

section.title: Which of the following is a secondary source?
section.content: Which of the following is a secondary source? Correct - Click anywhere to continue Incorrect - Click anywhere to continue You answered this correctly! Your answer: The correct answer is: You did not answer this question completely You must answer the question before continuing Submit Submit Clear Clear A) Statute B) Case C) Encyclopedia D) Regulation

section.title: Use a legal dictionary
section.content: Use a legal dictionary Correct - Click anywhere to continue Incorrect - Click anywhere to continue You answered this correctly! Your answer: The correct answer is: You did not answer this question completely You must answer the question before continuing Submit Submit Clear Clear A) To find synonyms B) To find definitions of legal latin terms C) To find judicial interpretations of a term D) All of the Above E) None of the Above

section.title: Encyclopedias are a great resource for background information

Your answer: The correct answer is: You did not answer this question completely You must answer the question before continuing Submit Submit Clear Clear A) True B) False

section.title: American Law Reports
section.content: American Law Reports Annotations (also called articles) = summaries of cases from a variety of jurisdictions Topics very specific. Case summaries arranged according to how the courts have ruled.

section.title: Researching ALRs
section.content: Researching ALRs
Index to the Annotation
Article Outline
Table of Jurisdictions

section.title: Locating Periodical Articles
section.content: Locating Periodical Articles Find articles through indexes Index to Legal Periodicals (Print or Westlaw @ ILP) Current Law Index (print or Westlaw @ LRI) Full text online HeinOnline Westlaw @ JLR Lexis @ US Law Reviews and Journals, Combined

section.title: Quiz Instructions - Quiz
section.content: Quiz Instructions - Quiz Let’s see what you’ve learned! Please answer the following questions … Click Play or Next button on Playbar to start the quiz

section.title: Match the ALR tool with how you would use it.
section.content: Match the ALR tool with how you would use it. Column 1 Column 2 Correct - Click anywhere to continue Incorrect - Click anywhere to continue You answered this correctly! Your answer: The correct answer is: You did not answer this question completely You must answer the question before continuing A. To find out which courts have ruled negatively or positively on an issue. B. To locate something very specific in the annotation C. To update the annotation D. To find an annotation dealing with a certain topic E. To find cases from a particular jurisdiction within an annotation D ALR Complete Series Index B Annotation Index E Table of Jurisdictions A Annotation Outline C Pocket Part or Supplements Submit Submit Clear Clear

section.title: Cite to an ALR annotation to support an argument in a brief.
section.content: Cite to an ALR annotation to support an argument in a brief. Correct - Click anywhere to continue Incorrect - Click anywhere to continue You answered this correctly! Your answer: The correct answer is: You did not answer this question completely You must answer the question before continuing A) True B) False Submit Submit Clear Clear

section.title: Use an ALR to
section.content: Use an ALR to Correct - Click anywhere to continue Incorrect - Click anywhere to continue You answered this correctly! Your answer: The correct answer is: You did not answer this question completely You must answer the question before continuing A) Survey the law across several states B) Research a narrow and specific issue C) Find cases on an issue that courts in your jurisdiction have not yet ruled on D) Get a sense of how the law is trending on an issue E) All of the above F) None of the above Submit Submit Clear Clear

section.title: Treatises
section.content: Treatises Covers one subject in depth- often multi-volumes or loose-leaf format Treatises are NOT: CLE material Practice sets Handbooks ALRS Encyclopedias Study aids or nutshells Restatements Government documents

section.title: Locating Material in Treatises
section.content: Locating Material in Treatises Methods Index (print only for most titles) Table of Contents (print & online) Key word searches (online only) TIP Information is grouped by general category within treatise so similar topics are proximate to each other

section.title: Restatements
section.content: Restatements Summaries of the rules of common law. Source for finding cases on point Objective is to highlight generally accepted rules Influential with the courts

section.title: Restatements
